_data.text:
## Need or Curiosity

Sometimes we have the need or the curiosity to know the temps of our hardware and adjust the fans accordingly. On windows it is an easy task using [HWiNFO](https://www.hwinfo.com/) for monitoring, and the proprietary software to control fans; there is a great variety of software to do it.

On Linux (Kubuntu this time), is not that straightforward but it is easy too.


## Sensors

Quick [Google Search](https://techhut.tv/monitor-amd-ryzen-temps-in-linux/) and we get the monitoring software: __lm-sensors__.

First, we install it:

```
apt install lm-sensors
```

Then, scan the system:

```
sensors-detect
```

After the scan, we can use `sensors` to get the temps, but it is not that pretty, so we can install `psensor`:

```
apt-get install lm-sensors hddtemp psensor
```

Now we can open __Psensor__ just as any other application.


## Control Fans

Now, the fans. Even though we can use the BIOS settings to control the CPU and system fans, we still need more software to control de GPU ones.


### CoreCtrl for AMD GPUs

Using [CoreCtrl](https://gitlab.com/corectrl/corectrl/) we can do more than just tweak the fan speeds, but for this time we are only focusing on that.

First, we have to add an _untrusted_ PPA, so proceed only if you can trust it.

```
add-apt-repository ppa:ernstp/mesarc
apt-get update
```

Then install `corectrl`:

```
apt install corectrl
```

Again, run __CoreCtrl__ as an application.

There are other ways of installing CoreCtrl on its [GitLab repository](https://gitlab.com/corectrl/corectrl/#installation).


### NVIDIA X Server Settings

On __System Settings__ go to __Driver Manager > Aditional Drivers__ and install the NVIDIA driver. Now, more [Google Searching](https://www.techticity.com/howto/how-to-control-nvidia-graphics-card-fan-speed-in-linux/):

```
nvidia-xconfig -a --cool-bits=28 --allow-empty-initial-configuration
```

This gets us the __NVIDIA X Server Settings__, that besides other configurations, we can use the __Thermal Settings__ to control the fans.

Now, our [reference](https://www.techticity.com/howto/how-to-control-nvidia-graphics-card-fan-speed-in-linux/#automatically) tell us there is [another option](https://github.com/nan0s7/nfancurve) to create a fan curve (that needs the previous step _in order to enable fan control_), but for now the curiosity ends here.

_data.title: Normalize Audio on Kubuntu

children.value: There are moments when the volume differences are so huge that is annoying, this creates the need to have a normalizer to take care of them.
that does a decent job and it can be easily enabled. But on Linux/Kubuntu we have to do
a little more than checking a box

.nofail
.include /etc/pulse/default.pa
load-module module-ladspa-sink  sink_name=ladspa_sink  plugin=dyson_compress_1403  label=dysonCompress  control=0,1,0.5,0.99
load-module module-ladspa-sink  sink_name=ladspa_normalized  master=ladspa_sink  plugin=fast_lookahead_limiter_1913  label=fastLookaheadLimiter  control=10,0,0.8
set-default-sink ladspa_normalized

_data.text:
## Too high and too low

There are moments when the volume differences are so huge that is annoying, this creates the need to have a normalizer to take care of them.

## Normalizing

Windows got something called __Loudness Equalization__ that does a decent job and it can be easily enabled. But on Linux/Kubuntu we have to do [a little more than checking a box](https://askubuntu.com/a/771628).

0. Install: `apt-get install swh-plugins`
0. Create the file: `~/.config/pulse/default.pa`

```[~/.config/pulse/default.pa]
.nofail
.include /etc/pulse/default.pa
load-module module-ladspa-sink  sink_name=ladspa_sink  plugin=dyson_compress_1403  label=dysonCompress  control=0,1,0.5,0.99
load-module module-ladspa-sink  sink_name=ladspa_normalized  master=ladspa_sink  plugin=fast_lookahead_limiter_1913  label=fastLookaheadLimiter  control=10,0,0.8
set-default-sink ladspa_normalized
```

2. Execute: `pulseaudio -k`

Now the __Audio Volume Settings__ will look like this:

![Audio Volume Settings](/post-img/normalize-audio/settings.png)

_data.title: Configure Logitech MX Anywhere 2s Mouse on Kubuntu

children.value: It is easy to configure the
on Windows, you just need to install the Logitech software and you're done, but for linux it's a little bit tricky.
A quick Google search led me to the
, that might not just work only for this particular mouse, but for others too.
Even though it is a very straightforward solution, there are some details to be aware of.
Connecting the mouse through bluetooth didn't work for me, so using its wireless adapter is a must.
The Battery status shows 55% most of the time, even with a full charged battery. It still displays 10% and 5% when needed.
Find out the mouse key associations with:
For Copy and Paste lateral buttons:
. But to be fair, it does not do much for this mouse.

_data.text:
## The mouse

It is easy to configure the [MX Anywhere](https://www.logitech.com/en-us/eol/mx-anywhere-2s-mouse.910-005132.html) on Windows, you just need to install the Logitech software and you're done, but for linux it's a little bit tricky.

A quick Google search led me to the [easiest solution](https://lgallardo.com/2020/08/06/2020-08-06-logitech-mx-anywhere-2s-flounder-on-linux/), that might not just work only for this particular mouse, but for others too.

Even though it is a very straightforward solution, there are some details to be aware of.

## The details

- Connecting the mouse through bluetooth didn't work for me, so using its wireless adapter is a must.
- The Battery status shows 55% most of the time, even with a full charged battery. It still displays 10% and 5% when needed.

## Quick setup

0. Install __xbindkeys__ and __xdotool__: `sudo apt install xbindkeys xdotool`
0. Find out the mouse key associations with: `xev | grep button`
0. Create the __.xbindkeysrc__ file: `xbindkeys --defaults > ~/.xbindkeysrc`
0. For Copy and Paste lateral buttons:

```bash[.xbindkeysrc]
"xdotool key --clearmodifiers ctrl+c"
  b:8

"xdotool key --clearmodifiers ctrl+v"
  b:9
```

4. Then, execute: `xbindkeys`

## Solaar

Optionally, you can install [Solaar](https://github.com/pwr-Solaar/Solaar): `apt install solaar`. But to be fair, it does not do much for this mouse.

_data.title: Toggle Keyboard Lights on Kubuntu

Key turns the lights on and off. Though that does not work on Linux/Kubuntu.

_data.text:
## The keyboard

I got a keyboard with simple lights, the __Cooler Master Devastator II Blue__; just pressing the __ScrLk__ Key turns the lights on and off. Though that does not work on Linux/Kubuntu.

## Turning lights on and off

[The workaround](https://askubuntu.com/a/158482) is simple, open the terminal, then write `xset led named "Scroll Lock"` for lights, and `xset -led named "Scroll Lock"` for no lights.

But it gets tiring to do that every time, so it is best to edit the `~/.profile` file so we can get the lights on without writing it ourselves again:

```bash[~/.profile]
# ...
xset led named "Scroll Lock"
```

This is going to execute every time after login in.

_data.description: Full native-like scroll behavior for Vue or Nuxt apps
_data.title: Vue Router Scroll Behavior

toc.text: Get back to the saved position

children.value: , we can get lost while navigating inside our app, especially when using the browser history.

E.g., let's say we are at the home page and we scroll down, then we click on a link to another page of the site. Now we are at the bottom of the new page (or at least at the same scroll position that we were at the last one). We scroll up and then press the back button on the browser; now we are not at the same position we were before getting into the new page.
Probably not a big deal for some cases, but we can improve this behavior.
gives us the necessary code fragments to fix this issue:
We can always start at the top of the page. This way we don't have to do unnecessary scrolling.
